title: Fundamentals of Sanatana Dharma

core_concepts.definition: Dharma means 'that which upholds'. It is righteousness, duty, moral law, and the cosmic order that sustains the universe.
core_concepts.explanation: Dharma is not just religion - it is the eternal principles that govern right living, ethical conduct, and harmonious existence.

core_concepts.teaching: These ten virtues are universal dharma - applicable to all humans regardless of birth, status, or circumstance.

core_concepts.svadharma: One's personal duty based on nature, stage of life, and circumstances
core_concepts.samanya_dharma: Universal duties applicable to all (non-violence, truth, etc.)
core_concepts.principle: When in conflict, svadharma may take precedence, but never at the cost of core ethical principles.

core_concepts.relationship: Dharma guides right action; karma is the law of cause and effect
core_concepts.teaching: Live according to dharma, and your karma becomes a vehicle for spiritual evolution rather than bondage.

key_principles: Ahimsa (Non-violence) - in thought, word, and deed
Satya (Truth) - but truth must be beneficial, not harmful
Asteya (Non-stealing) - even in subtle forms like time, ideas
Brahmacharya (Self-control) - mastery over desires and senses
Dharma is context-dependent - what is right depends on time, place, circumstance
The greatest dharma is compassion toward all beings
When in doubt, ask: 'What would a wise, compassionate person do?'
